I wrote a post for Smashing Magazine that was published today about this thing that Chrome and Safari have called ‚ÄúTight Mode‚Äù and how it impacts page performance. I‚Äôd never heard the term until DebugBear‚Äôs Matt Zeunert mentioned it in ‚Ä¶

articles.title: An Ode To Side Project Time

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Joas Pambou)
articles.description: Shouldn‚Äôt there be a way to keep your apps or project data private and improve performance by reducing server latency? This is what on-device AI is designed to solve. It handles AI processing locally, right on your device, without connecting to the internet and sending data to the cloud. In this article, Joas Pambou explains what on-device AI is, why it‚Äôs important, the tools to build this type of technology, and how it can change the way we use technology every day.
articles.title: On-Device AI: Building Smarter, Faster, And Private Applications

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Thomas Bohm)
articles.description: How do we determine the most suitable illustration style? How should illustrations complement and reflect your corporate identity? What will resonate most with your target audience? And regarding the content, what type of illustration would best enhance it, and how would it work for the age range it is primarily for? Thomas Bohm shares insightful examples and discusses the key qualities of effective illustrations, emphasizing the importance of understanding your audience.
articles.title: The Role Of Illustration Style In Visual Storytelling

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Victor Ayomipo)
articles.description: The best and worst thing about solo development is the ‚Äúsolo‚Äù part. There‚Äôs a lot of freedom in working alone, and that freedom can be inspiring, but it can also become a debilitating hindrance to productivity and progress. Victor Ayomipo shares his personal lessons on what it takes to navigate solo development and build the ‚Äúright‚Äù app.
articles.title: Solo Development: Learning To Let Go Of Perfection

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: We know that browsers do all sorts of different things under the hood. One of those things is the way they not only *fetch* resources like images and scripts from the server but how they [prioritize those resources](https://www.debugbear.com/blog/request-priorities?utm_campaign=sm-7). Chrome and Safari have implemented a ‚ÄúTight Mode‚Äù that constrains which resources are loaded and in what order, but they each take drastically different approaches to it. With so little information about Tight Mode available, this article attempts a high-level explanation of what it is, what triggers it, and how it is treated differently in major browsers.
articles.title: Tight Mode: Why Browsers Produce Different Performance Results

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (John Rhea)
articles.description: HTML attributes are like little instructions that we add to the markup of elements to make them do certain things or behave in certain ways. For example, most of us know that the `target` attribute with a value of `_blank` opens the link in a new tab or window. But did you know that you can use it on the `form` element, too? John Rhea presents several lesser-known uses for common HTML attributes.
articles.title: Lesser Known Uses Of Better Known Attributes

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Saad Khan)
articles.description: Product drops and sales are a great way to increase revenue, but these events can result in traffic spikes that affect a site‚Äôs availability and performance. To prevent website crashes, you‚Äôll have to make sure that the sites you design can handle large numbers of server requests at once. Let‚Äôs discuss how!
articles.title: How To Design For High-Traffic Events And Prevent Your Website From Crashing

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Atila Fassina)
articles.description: We, as human beings, don‚Äôt worry too much about making sure the connections land at the right point. Our brain just works that way, declaratively. However, for building AI, we need to be more explicit. Let‚Äôs dive in!
articles.title: What Does AI Really Mean?
